questions.text: The average 70 kg male can be considered to consist of fat and fat free mass. In this individual weight of minerals is_______
questions.solution:
• The average 70 kg male can be considered to consist of fat (13 kg) and fat-free mass (or lean body mass: 57 kg). In such an individual, the lean tissue is composed primarily of protein (12 kg), water (42 kg) and minerals (3 kg).
  • The protein mass can be considered as two basic compartments: Skeletal Muscle (4 kg) and Non-Skeletal Muscle (8 kg), which includes the visceral protein mass. The water mass (42 litres) is divided into intracellular (28 litres) and extracellular (14 litres) spaces.
  • Most of the mineral mass is contained in the bony skeleton.

Topic: Chemical body composition

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; Chapter 1; page number 7.

questions.text: A 14-year-old female patient was diagnosed as a case of acute appendicitis. She has a past history of hemarthrosis. On evaluation, she was a known case of factor VIII deficiency. So decision was taken to give her cryoprecipitate before the operation. Cryoprecipitate is rich in all of the following except________
questions.solution:
• Cryoprecipitate is a supernatant precipitate of FFP and is rich in fibrinogen, factor VIII and factor XIII.
  • It is stored at -30°C with a 2-year shelf life.
  • It is given in low fibrinogen states or factor VIII deficiency.

Topic: Cryoprecipitate

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 2; page number 21.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient was posted for open appendectomy. Prophylactic antibiotic was given 30 minutes before incision. The tissue levels of antibiotics during the period when bacterial contamination is likely to occur should be above _______ for the expected pathogens.
questions.solution:
• There is up to a 4-hour interval before bacterial growth becomes established enough to cause an infection after a breach in the tissues, whether caused by trauma or by surgery.
  • This interval is called the "Decisive Period" and strategies aimed at preventing infection from taking a hold become ineffective after this time period.
  • It is therefore logical that prophylactic antibiotics should be given to cover this period and that they could be decisive in preventing an infection from developing before bacterial growth takes a hold.
  • The tissue levels of antibiotics during the period when bacterial contamination is likely to occur should be above the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC90) for the expected pathogens.

Topic: Decisive period

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 5; page number :54.

questions.text: According to the Surviving Sepsis Campaign, a patient who is in septic shock, one should take all of the following three from the patient within 6 hours.
questions.solution:
• The sepsis bundle, also known as the Resuscitation Bundle, is a combination of evidence-based objectives that must be completed within 6 hours for patients presenting with severe sepsis, septic shock and/or lactate >4 mmol/L.
  • The Sepsis Six is the name given to a bundle of medical therapies designed to reduce mortality in patients with sepsis.
  • Drawn from International guidelines that emerged from the Surviving Sepsis Campaign, the Sepsis Six was developed by the UK’s Sepsis Trust.
  • The componnts of the Sepsis Six are:
    • give three to patients:
      1. intravenous fluid challenge,
      2. intravenous antibiotics,
      3. oxygen and monitor urine output;
    • take three from patients:
      1. blood cultures,
      2. full blood count,
      3. lactate.

Topic: Sepsis six

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 5; page number 59.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presented to Emergency with complaints of severe abdominal pain and abdominal distension since last 1 day. Abdominal X-ray seen in below image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The Rigler sign, also known as the double-wall sign, is a sign of pneumoperitoneum seen on an abdominal radiograph when gas is outlining both sides of the bowel wall, i.e. gas within the bowel's lumen and gas within the peritoneal cavity.

intestinal obstruction :

  • The obstructed small bowel is characterized by straight segments that are generally central and lie transversely. No/ minimal gas is seen in the colon
  • The jejunum is characterized by its valvulae conniventes, which completely pass across the width of the bowel and are regularly spaced, giving a 'concertina' or ladder effect
  • Ileum - the distal ileum is featureless
  • A distended caecum appears as a rounded gas shadow in the right iliac fossa
  • Large bowel, except for the caecum, shows haustral folds, which, unlike valvulae conniventes, are spaced irregularly, do not cross the whole diameter of the bowel and do not have indentations placed opposite one another


Acute pancreatitis :The abdominal radiograph is not diagnostic and frequently normal or may demonstrate:


  1. sentinel loop
  2. colon cut off
  3. diffuse ileus
  4. pleural effusion

Acute appendicitis :

  • Fecalith may be seen on xray with appendicitis

Topic: Conventional radiography

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 8; page number 123, 137,138.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient was brought to the Emergency Department after a road traffic accident. On Examination, she suffered from a severe head injury. The initial aim of resuscitation is to maintain the blood supply to the vital organs: the brain, heart and kidneys. In case of head injury, systolic blood pressure of > 90 mm Hg should be the target. To achieve this target, which of the following should be used?
questions.solution:
• The initial aim of resuscitation is to maintain the blood supply to the vital organs: the brain, heart and kidneys.
  • For a short time, this can be achieved with a target systolic blood pressure of 70-90 mmHg, although a higher pressure of >90 mmHg should be the target if a head injury is suspected.
  • Small boluses of IV fluids (e.g. 250 mL of O negative blood, or normal saline if blood is not immediately available) should be administered to achieve this target, which should result in a palpable radial pulse.
  • Excessive IV crystalloid or colloid solutions should be avoided because they cause haemodilution, increase coagulopathy and increase the risk of adult respiratory distress syndrome.

Topic: Resuscitation

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 27; page number 355.

questions.text: The following image shows the various herniation of the brain after brain hemorrhage. The CUSHING'S triad is seen in which type of herniation?
questions.solution:
• Cerebellar tonsillar herniation through the foramen magnum compresses medullary vasomotor and respiratory centers, classically producing Cushing's triad.
  • Cushing's triad: Hypertension, Bradycardia and Irregular Respiration. the patient is then said to be 'coning', and brainstem death will result without immediate intervention.

Topic :CUSHING'S triad

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 28 ; page number 361.

questions.text: A 27 years old patient presented to emergency after road traffic accident. His clinical photograph is given below. Identity the sign seen in this photograph
questions.solution:
Clinical evidence of a skull base fracture may include Battle's sign and "racoon" or "panda" eyes (bilateral periorbital bruising).

Option A and B: racoon eye and panda eye sign

Seen in basal skull fracture, orbital bone fracture


Topic: Battle's sign

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 28 ; page number 364.

questions.text: A 20 years old football player had a history of head injury while playing football on the ground. At that time, he had an episode of transient loss of consciousness. After some time period, patient had headache but without any neurological deficit. This patient was brought to the emergency with sudden collapse and declared dead. This pattern of 'talk and die' is seen in which type of intracranial hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
• Extradural haematoma is a neurosurgical emergency. It results from rupture of an artery, vein or venous sinus, in association with a skull fracture.
  • The classical injury is a fracture to the thin squamous temporal bone, with associated damage to the Middle Meningeal Artery.
  • Transient loss of consciousness is typical, and the patient may then present in the subsequent lucid interval with headache but without any neurological deficit. As the haematoma expands, compensation is exhausted (The Monro-Kellie doctrine and herniation syndrome) with rapid deterioration.
  • a lucid interval is a temporary improvement in a patient's condition after a traumatic brain injury, after which the condition deteriorates. A lucid interval is especially indicative of an epidural hematoma.
  • There is contralateral hemiparesis, a reduced conscious level and ipsilateral pupillary dilatation; the cardinal signs of brain compression and herniation.
  • Although this 'talk and die' pattern of deterioration occurs in only one-third of cases; it is critically important to recognize the potential for rapid avoidable secondary brain injury in patients who present neurologically intact.

Topic :Extra dural haematoma

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 28; page number 365.

choices.text: Posterior to the lateral border of pectoralis major
Inferiorly by a line perpendicular to the nipple going to back
Just posterior to the mid axillary line

questions.text: A 28 year old male patient was brought to the emergency department with difficulty in breathing after a road traffic accident. His chest X-ray was given below. All of the following are true about the location of inserting the chest tube except__________
questions.solution:
This is the case of tension pneumothorax.


Treatment consists of immediate decompression.

This was historically taught by rapid insertion of a large-bore cannula into the second intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line of the affected side, followed by insertion of a chest tube through the fifth intercostal space in the anterior axillary line.


However, current teaching advocates undertaking decompression in the safe triangle - defined posteriorly by latissimus dorsi, anteriorly by the lateral border of pectoralis major and inferiorly by a line perpendicular to the nipple going to the back, just anterior to the mid-axillary line - or, in extremis, a finger thoracostomy at the same location

Topic: ICD

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 29; page number 374.

questions.text: The following maneuver given in the image is used in the management of liver trauma. This manoeuvre can control the bleeding from all of the following options except________
questions.solution:
• The operative management of liver injuries can be summarized as 'the four Ps':
    • Pressure;
    • Pringle;
    • Plug;
    • Pack.
  • At laparotomy the liver is reconstituted and bleeding is controlled by direct bimanual compression to achieve its normal architecture as best as possible (Pressure).
  • The inflow from the portal triad is controlled by a Pringle's manoeuvre, with direct compression of the portal triad, either digitally or using a soft clamp.
  • This has the effect of reducing arterial and portal venous inflow into the liver, although it does not control the backflow from the inferior vena cava and hepatic veins.

Topic :Pringle's manoeuvre

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 29 ; page number 380,381.

choices.text: stage III - Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
stage IV - Control of haemorrhage and control of contamination

questions.text: A 64-year-old male patient was presented to OPD with complaints of bilateral inguinal swelling. On examination, he had bilateral direct inguinal hernia. Surgeon decided to operate. On preoperative evaluation, the patient's blood pressure was 180/ 110 mmHg. So Physician advised to start an oral anti-hypertensive drug. In this case, a new antihypertensive agent was introduced, a stabilization period of at least _____ weeks should be allowed.
questions.solution:
• Prior to elective surgery blood pressure should be controlled to <160/100 mmHg. If a new antihypertensive agent is introduced, a stabilization period of at least 2 weeks should be allowed.

Topic: Hypertension
